text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Ayn and Bill Vernon. Gordon R. Dixon is one of the all-time professionals in science fiction. He's been writing this stuff full-time for over 30 years. Besides an uncountable number of short stories, he's published such novels as Dorsi, The Pritcher Mass, The Dragon and the George, and The Star Sailors. He's also won Hugo and Nebula awards for his science fiction, and he served as president of the Science Fiction Writers of America. We asked Dixon if he had always been a full-time writer. Dixon was a major in creative writing. Dixon was a major in creative writing, and World War II came along before I was able to get my B.A. So I was out for three or four years, I forget which, something like that. Then I went back and spent another two years, went into graduate school. At the time, it's about the only time in my life when I ever considered doing anything but writing. I was playing with the idea then of holding down a teaching job, going on and getting my doctorate in English and teaching, and doing the writing on the side. After World War II, we were all hypersensible. Everybody was very cool-headed, and let's have this nonsense over with. Get down and get to work someplace. And luckily, I came out of that and said, this is silly. I never intended to do anything but writing. And instead of having the teaching pay for the writing, why not make the writing pay for the writing? So I simply dived out of graduate school into full-time writing for the magazines. Dixon published his first story in a science fiction magazine around 1950, and by writing for the pulps, he was able to support himself. So actually, I dived in and kept myself in place writing for the magazines for about three or four years. And then I, somewhere about 1954, I did my first science fiction novel. So I've been full-time as a writer since 1950. Now, I'd sold things before that. I'd sold a magazine piece, I think as early as 1942. And I had something in my magazine, a short, short story in a magazine section of a Minneapolis paper. And I'd been in the Toronto Star Weekly, which was a magazine supplement. It went along with the Toronto Star Journal. Star Journal? Ah, can't remember the name of the newspaper. Dixon reveals more about his background and his literary preferences. You see, the thing is that I always intended to be a writer. And about for the first 30 years of my life, I was simply looking for the type of thing I wanted to write. But I cut my teeth on poetry. If I had been born in the late 19th century, I would have been at home because I would have done long narrative poems like Idols of the King. You know, Tennyson's and Iowans and things like this. As it is, we're in a non-poetic age. And I finally ended up saying, well, to do what I want to do, I'm going to have to use the medieval historical novel. And then simply because magazines were putting bread and butter on the table, and I found out I like science fiction best. I like writing science fiction best. I ended up doing essentially nothing but science fiction. And as I did this, I came to realize the possibilities of that particular field for what I wanted to do. What Dixon wanted to do was an ambitious undertaking, to publish a series of 12 novels dealing with man's ethical evolution. He's still working on the series, called The Child Cycle. Some of the novels in it are Necromancer, Dorsi, and The Tactics of Mistake. We'll talk more with Gordon Dixon next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Child Cycle Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, The Child Cycle Association, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Gordon Dixon has written highly popular science fiction for over three decades, but during that time he's been most concerned with one major vision, a series of novels called The Child Cycle. The series will be at least 12 novels long. The books will be set in the past, the present, and the future, and they will deal with what Dixon calls the ethical evolution of man. Some of the novels have already been written, Dorsi being perhaps the best known of them. Dixon says that when he began writing science fiction, he realized the possibilities that the field offered him to pursue his vision. And of course what I want to do is now take in shape long since 20 years ago as The Child Cycle of Novels, which is, when it's done, will cover a thousand years. There will be three historical novels, starting with one about Sir John Hawkwood, who was an Englishman of the 13th century, who ended up as Captain General of the military forces for Florence, Italy, and will end in the 23rd century with Child, C-H-I-L-D-E, the novel from which the whole series takes its name. And the whole series effectively, the stories don't chronologically follow each other. They're connected thematically. And what they represent is sort of a literary thematic argument, something that has never been done before, actually, which argues, a philosophical point, in fact, it argues that we're undergoing evolution right now. It's not physical evolution or mental evolution. It's a, there's no really good word for it. You could call it spiritual evolution, but that isn't right either. It's an ethical evolution. We're, of necessity, we're evolving what I call a responsible human being. And we're sort of halfway there from the time of the third, from the viewpoint of the 13th century toward the 23rd. We're halfway to developing the responsible human being. Dixon explains what he means by the responsible human being. If you assume that, oh, insanity is going to be brought under control unless civilization goes crash within the next 50 or 100 years, if not a lot sooner, that is going to give you a population of sane people. But even a population of sane people can have individuals who, for their own purposes, are willing to destroy things. Now, back in the days of the flint axe and the stone club, if a particular caveman decided to run wild and start bopping people over the head, he could probably kill two or three others before everybody ganged up on him and stopped him. And that's escalated up to our time where somebody who knows how can set up a laboratory in the basement and blow up a large-sized city or part of a state. And you extrapolate the curve of destructive possibility and you see that within, well, probably less than the 300 to 500 years I give us, you're going to have a situation where any individual can destroy the whole race unless some such sense of the responsibility is developed. And what the historical novels do and the contemporary novels do is what a good, hard science fiction story does, and that is they lay out the evidence of what we know and then extrapolate forward from there, saying, all right, if this and this and this is so, and we know it to be so, then doesn't this develop from it? You know, and if I'm wrong in my hypothesis, point out where I'm wrong. And so the whole cycle becomes essentially sort of one large science fiction story, even though it covers historical, contemporary, and future novels. More with Gordon Dixon next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. www. nebenist.info. Ov DDL Or no ignore? Or no Handiera? Or well. Or yeah, okay. Thank you. Thank you. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. Actually, it isn't really. The cycle is made with three archetypes, three human archetypes, one of which is the warrior, one of which is the philosopher, and one of which is the faith holder. Now, the historical novels show the warrior, the faith holder, and the philosopher. However, in the person of people, we can look up in history books. The 20th century will show them at work in our century. The future ones show them in the projected and problematical future. But the warrior is only one of three types, all of which is equally necessary. Now, the reason the emphasis on the military is there is for two reasons. One is, this caught the eye of the publishers, and they packaged the books as military-oriented books. And, in fact, the ones that dealt with warrior types, like Donald Graham, the first one, Dorsi, where Donald Graham is a warrior archetype, were legitimate to do it that way. But then they began publishing all the things this way. That is part of it. The other part of it is that since all the cycle must be sound, must be watertight, is that the military elements in there are justified, are logicalized. So I don't blame people for being led astray in this particular fashion. But if they will look closely at the cycle, they will see it isn't true. And about the only people I have any quarrel with are those who, without reading things, simply make the assumption that this is a militaristically oriented series of books. When Dixon published Dorsi in 1959, he hadn't yet thought of the idea of a large cycle in which that novel would only be a part. He says the idea of the cycle came to him when he went to the Milford Science Fiction Conference in Pennsylvania in 1960. And while I was up there, I hit one night, one asthmatic night, when I was exhausted and I thought, well, maybe I'll sleep through. And asthmatics tell them, of course you don't. I woke up an hour later and saw it. People don't know how to do it. It's a matter of getting breath in. It's a matter of getting breath out. You swell up with air that you can't exhale. And your adrenaline level goes off the top of the map. You're physically incapacitated and the mind just gallops. I was way off in the woods, effectively, and there was nothing to be done until dawn, at which time other people would be up and they could drive me to the nearest doctor or clinic or what have you. And so I had nothing to do but sit there for five hours and wait for the sun to rise. And in that time, I worked out the pattern for this cycle completely, from soup to nuts with every book in its place, or rather every, I shouldn't say every book, because the numbers of books have doubled because of the size of what's being done. But it's a case of the original books more or less being split down the middle, you see, because they're too big to publish, as it shows. We'll continue talking with Gordon Dixon on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Thank you. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Science fiction author Gordon Dixon has been working on his ambitious child cycle for over 20 years. When completed, the cycle will encompass at least 12 novels and will describe the ethical evolution of man. Dorsi, the first novel written in the series, though not the first chronologically, was published in a serial and astounding magazine in 1959. We asked Dixon if his overall plan is still based on a 12-novel series. Yes. The original plan was for six novels. Let me see. No, for nine novels. Pardon me. Three historical, three late in the 20th century, and three late in the future. Because I started on the future length first, it was there I first discovered that each book was going to be too big to get into one set of covers. And I was up against the fact that publishers refused to print category fiction in lengths of much more than 100,000 words at that time. Remember, the first big book to come out actually was Frank Herbert's Dune, which antidates Dorsi, which happened earlier, about, I think, four or six years, something like that. And Dune was printed only because one editor in particular practically, well, laid his job online and practically offered to shoot up the publishing house unless they went after it. And they chewed their fingernails, you know, because there's a great deal of money involved in printing a very large book. This is still the case, even with paperbacks, even in paperback. It's very expensive to do a big-type book. So these things had to be cut, pardon me, I mean they had to be divided into smaller chunks. And the result was I ended up with three historical, three contemporary, and six forward. Now, of that six forward, Final Encyclopedia, at 1,400 pages, is so big that Child, which should have been, see that Final Encyclopedia is the penultimate novel. The last one, the ultimate one, is Child. And obviously, if Final Encyclopedia is 1,400, Child would have run close to 2,000 manuscript pages, which is far too big. So I've had to split that again. So effectively, what we have now is not 12, but 13 novels. What about the works that are set in the past, the historical novels? Will Dixon stick to his original plan for a set of three? I think there's a pretty good chance, except in the case of Hawkwood. And the problem with that is that Sir John Hawkwood, the actual man, lived a very long time by medieval standards. An astonishingly long time when you just stop to think that most of his adult life was spent in hand-to-hand combat wearing armor. He actually lived into his 70s. And he covered in that time what, by modern standards, would have been three or four lifetimes. He starts out in Sibyl-Heddingham, England, which is out in the boondocks of Essex in his time, literally, when Essex was mainly forest. And ends up in Florence, Italy, which at that time was the center of Western civilization. So effectively, he traveled in subjective time about 150 to 180 years in terms of moving forward with the pattern of civilization. More with Gordon Dixon next time. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Any art requires an instant amount of work. And who hasn't said that the definition of art was the taking of infinite things or words without a fact. But the point is, the person doing it enjoys it or he doesn't do it. I'm fascinated with the work I do. You wonder, for example, how a concert pianist can practice five hours a day, week after week, month after month, year after year. You think if you're a non-piano player or if you had piano playing lessons pushed on you and didn't like them when you were young, that this must be a self-imposed agony. It is. It's a sheer pleasure for him to get things just right. And this, of course, is the battle cry of the artist. It's to get things just right. When we asked Dixon if he has to do a lot of rewriting, he alluded to a book he had just finished and that should be published soon, the final encyclopedia. I write and rewrite and rewrite and rewrite again. This last book, sections of it were written once and barely touched again. Other sections were written in notable times. I really couldn't tell you how many, ten or more, ten, fifteen times to get it just right. I can't re-read anything I've written without picking up a pencil and starting to correct and improve it. It's instinctive. Most writers have this kind of reaction to a certain extent, although some rewrite more, some rewrite less. There is a type of writer that doesn't rewrite but instead sits and does nothing for a long time and then sits down and does it just the way he or she wants it. And that possibly is the hardest work of all because it's all being done in the end. I do it on paper. And of course, the fact that I use a computer to write with Valdez makes it that much easier, makes it that much faster. Dixon says that science fiction has developed over the years, a natural progression from the hardware stories of the late 20s and early 30s. What was printed in the late 1920s and the early 1930s went through a period of development when John Gamble took over his founding and the concept of the hard science fiction story and also something else, the idea story, which is essentially a thematic science fiction story. It began with John in the 30s. And that period has developed and gone on. They were originally hardware stories, originally science fiction. And that's, it's gone from hard science to essentially soft science. In other words, the subject, the scientific element, has gone from physics and chemistry to, or rather went from physics and chemistry into psychology and sociology and things like that. And with the emergence in the 60s of the excellent crop of women writers who have almost dominated the field since then, we've had the introduction of character into our stories. We have become more, much more stories of human interest. As has been pointed out and said, we've been exploring the inner universe as much as we've been exploring the outer universe, perhaps more. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. And that's what we've been exploring the world of the world of the world of the world of the world of the world of the world. Time to discover the future. Shred. If you have a man who saw this, he canрон theaufticipation as much as a lesson. But in the years, that this year we blessed to see less of this on sports spiciness. In that every minute, okay?

And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Ayn and Bill Vernon.
Gordon R. Dixon is one of the all-time professionals in science fiction.
He's been writing this stuff full-time for over 30 years.
Besides an uncountable number of short stories, he's published such novels as Dorsi, The Pritcher Mass, The Dragon and the George, and The Star Sailors.
He's also won Hugo and Nebula awards for his science fiction, and he served as president of the Science Fiction Writers of America.
We asked Dixon if he had always been a full-time writer.
Dixon was a major in creative writing.
Dixon was a major in creative writing, and World War II came along before I was able to get my B.A.
So I was out for three or four years, I forget which, something like that.

At the time, it's about the only time in my life when I ever considered doing anything but writing.

After World War II, we were all hypersensible.
Everybody was very cool-headed, and let's have this nonsense over with.
Get down and get to work someplace.
And luckily, I came out of that and said, this is silly.
I never intended to do anything but writing.
And instead of having the teaching pay for the writing, why not make the writing pay for the writing?
So I simply dived out of graduate school into full-time writing for the magazines.

It went along with the Toronto Star Journal.

Ah, can't remember the name of the newspaper.

You see, the thing is that I always intended to be a writer.
And about for the first 30 years of my life, I was simply looking for the type of thing I wanted to write.
But I cut my teeth on poetry.

You know, Tennyson's and Iowans and things like this.
As it is, we're in a non-poetic age.

I like writing science fiction best.
I ended up doing essentially nothing but science fiction.

Some of the novels in it are Necromancer, Dorsi, and The Tactics of Mistake.
